translated: Verses of the Elders
The Section of Sixteens
The First Chapter
The Elder Aññāsikoṇḍañña
I have even more confidence
in hearing the Dhamma of great meaning;
The Dhamma taught by the one free from passion
is without attachment in every way.
There are many wonders in the world,
on this circular earth;
They seem to disturb the mind,
the beautiful associated with passion.🔽But just as dust stirred up by the wind
settles when the sky is clear,
so too do thoughts settle
when one sees with wisdom.
“All conditioned things are impermanent” —
when one sees this with wisdom,
then one loses interest in suffering;
this is the path to purification.
“All conditioned things are suffering” —
when one sees this with wisdom,
then one loses interest in suffering;
this is the path to purification.
“All phenomena are not self” —
when one sees this with wisdom,
then one loses interest in suffering;
this is the path to purification.

analyzed: buddhānubuddhaḥ yaḥ theraḥ  koṇḍaññaḥ tibba nikkamaḥ
translated: The elder who was enlightened by the Buddha,🔽Koṇḍañña of great effort,
having abandoned birth and death,
and has completed the spiritual life.
The snare of craving, the strong fetter,
the mountain that is hard to break;
Having cut the snare and the fetter,
having broken the rock that is hard to break;
The meditator has crossed over, gone to the further shore,
he is freed from Māra’s bondage.
The monk who is restless and fickle,
who has come to bad friends;
He sinks in the great flood,
like a rock submerged by the waves.
